author: .vbuterin
content: One big problem of these "small privileged state vs big non-privileged state" architectures is that they're not sharding friendly

author: .vbuterin
content: Which is something that actually makes a lot of sense for contract code

author: .vbuterin
content: As we expect contract code to be duplicated and used everywhere, so we absolutely should have a buffer where commonly used code (libraries, account abstracted verification code, base ERC20 class....) lives

author: .vbuterin
content: Also we don't want to design an architecture around the idea that witnesses cost 1 kB bytes per item, because we know that they're going down to 64-200 bytes per item in half a decade, whether it's a verkle tree or SNARKs/STARKs or something totally new
